texts.shortText:
Large, conspicuous worm with two spiral crowns of mottled cream to orange or brown tentacles that bear a row of small lobes (variously referred to as stylodes or lappets) on their outer surface. Tiny eyespots at bases of each lapel visible under the microscope.

Body fat and sausage-like, shading brown to purple anteriorly and with a wide anterior collar enclosing (and secreting) the top of a soft, muddy, parchment-like tube.
Body typically 50 mm long, crown about 30 mm across.

Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Luderitz to False Bay. Despite the species name, not found in KwaZulu-Natal!

Found in intertidal pools and gullies and on shallow reefs. The tube usually extends from a crack or from under a boulder and the crown of feeding tentacles is extended into the water to intercept food particles. Snaps back into its tube rapidly at the slightest disturbance. Rejected food particles are used to construct the soft, muddy tube.
Filter-feeder, removing and consuming particulate material from the water passing through the crown of tentacles.

A variety of modes of reproduction occur in this group and most species can reproduce both asexually by ‘budding’ off smaller individuals, as well as sexually by producing sperm and eggs into the water column.

There are several other large fan worms in the region. The closely related B. violacea has a crown of tentacles of two semicircles. The external lappets on the feeding appendages distinguish these species from the more common and better-known feather duster worm Pseudobranchiomma longa. Can be distinguished from the Red fan worm Serpula vermicuaris and all other members of the related family Serpulidae since these have hard calcareous tubes, rather than soft muddy ones found in family Sabellidae.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 74).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 767).
